subject: RE: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test
msgSnippet: I think the only requirement for JUnit is that test names begin with test so that they can be run through intropsection. The goal with the numbers is not to
messageBody:
I think the only requirement for JUnit is that test names begin with
"test" so that they can be run through intropsection.

The goal with the numbers is not to make the tests order dependent,
but rather to organize the test methods.

We did consider using descriptive names for the test methods, for
example

test_isPartnerAssigned_nullArgument

However, this got to be real awkward real fast. So instead we choose
to use a number and put a comment before the test method to describe
what is being tested. The numbers actually enable you easily to know
how many test methods you have for a specific method.

As a correction, we are actually putting the numbers at the end of
the test method name:

test_nameOfMethodBeingTested_##

I agree that this system is only descriptive up to a point in telling
you the name of the method being tested. If someone has a better
suggestion please reply.

The basic question is, "When you have multiple test methods that test
a single method, what naming convention do you use for the test
methods?"


--- Jim Cheesman <jchees@...> wrote:
>
> >
> >I use the following naming convention for my test methods to keep
> >things organized:
> >
> > test_##_nameOfMethodBeingTested
> >
> >For example, the eigth test method for the method
> isAccountAssigned
> >would be,
> >
> > test_07_isAccountAssigned
>
>
>
> Doesn't this rather make your testing order dependent, which I
> believe
> cannot be guaranteed with JUnit? Why add the number if not?
> Shouldn't test
> cases have names that reflect their purpose (a la Refactoring) just
> as much
> as production code? This numbering rather defeats that... And if,
> say, test
> 07 fails - what does that tell me? That 01-06 and 08-12 have
> passed,
> and...???
>
>
>
>
>
> --
>
> * Jim Cheesman *
> Trabajo:
> jchees@... - (34)(91) 724 9200 x 2360
> Reality is a big, nasty, vicious
> dragon, but I don't believe in dragons.
>
